DataElement.preferredName: Radical Prostatectomy Prostate Negative Surgical Margin Other Spatial Relationship To Patient Text
DataElement.preferredDefinition: User entered text describing anatomic relationship of the radical prostatectomy negative margin to the patient.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Radical Prostatectomy Prostate Gland Negative Surgical Margin Other Patient Orientation
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Surgery to remove the entire prostate. The two types of radical prostatectomy are retropubic prostatectomy and perineal prostatectomy.:The walnut shaped accessory sex gland of the male reproductive system.  It is located in the pelvis just below the bladder, surrounding the prostatic part of the urethra.  The prostate gland secretes a fluid which is part of the semen.:definition pending_Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.:A person who receives medical attention, care, or treatment, or who is registered with medical professional or institution with the purpose to receive medical care when necessary.:Position or alignment relative to points of the compass or other specific directions.

ObjectClass.preferredName: Radical Prostatectomy Prostate Gland Negative Surgical Margin
ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Surgery to remove the entire prostate. The two types of radical prostatectomy are retropubic prostatectomy and perineal prostatectomy.:The walnut shaped accessory sex gland of the male reproductive system.  It is located in the pelvis just below the bladder, surrounding the prostatic part of the urethra.  The prostate gland secretes a fluid which is part of the semen.:definition pending

Concepts.definition: The surgical removal of all of the prostate as well as some surrounding tissue, including lymph nodes.

The walnut shaped accessory sex gland of the male reproductive system. It is located in the pelvis just below the bladder, surrounding the prostatic part of the urethra. The prostate gland secretes a fluid which is part of the semen.
Indicates the absence of tumor cells at the edge of a surgically excised specimen.
